dare.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to be brave enough to do something that is risky or that you are afraid to do – used especially in questions or negative sentences
dare.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: He wanted to ask her, but he didn’t dare.
Only a few journalists dared to cover the story.
She hardly dared hope that he was alive.
dare.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to try to persuade someone to do something dangerous or embarrassing as a way of proving that they are brave
dare.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: So jump, then. I dare you.
They dared Ed to steal a bottle of his father’s whiskey.
dare.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: You say that someone dares to do something
Not many people dared to argue
dare.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: Dare can also be used as a modal verb, followed by the base form  (=infinitive without ‘to’), especially in negatives and questions
dare.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: Don’t use a ‘to’ infinitive with daren’t You say
dare.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: Dare is not used in the progressive You say
I am not daring say anything
dare.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: something dangerous that you have dared someone to do
dare.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: She ran across a busy road for a dare.
